User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the Habitual application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the user entity.

createdAt.description: Timestamp indicating when the user account was created.

Habit.title: Habit
Habit.description: Represents a habit being tracked by a user.

id.description: Unique identifier for the habit entity.

userId.description: Reference to the User who owns this habit. (Relationship: User 1:N Habit)

description.description: A more detailed description of the habit.

frequency.description: The frequency with which the habit should be performed (e.g., daily, weekly).

createdAt.description: Timestamp indicating when the habit was created.

isActive.description: A boolean indicating whether the habit is currently active.

HabitLog.title: HabitLog
HabitLog.description: Represents a log of a user's habit completion on a specific date.

id.description: Unique identifier for the habit log entry.

habitId.description: Reference to the Habit being logged. (Relationship: Habit 1:N HabitLog)

userId.description: Reference to the User who performed the habit. (Relationship: User 1:N HabitLog)

date.description: The date on which the habit was logged (YYYY-MM-DD).

completed.description: A boolean indicating whether the habit was completed on the given date.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to ensure Authorization Independence, support the required QAPs, and provide a clear and predictable data model for the Habitual application. It leverages path-based ownership and segregation for enhanced security and simplified security rules. The database structure is:

`/users/{userId}`: Stores user profiles. Security rules will ensure that only the authenticated user can access their own profile data.

`/users/{userId}/habits/{habitId}`: Stores habits owned by a specific user. This path-based ownership simplifies security rules, ensuring that only the user who owns the habit can access it.

`/users/{userId}/habits/{habitId}/habitLogs/{habitLogId}`: Stores habit logs for a specific habit. This nested structure maintains the user-habit-habitLog relationship, ensuring clear ownership and simplifies access control.

Authorization Independence: The design enforces authorization independence by ensuring that each document's access control is determined solely by its path and the authenticated user's ID (`request.auth.uid`). There are no `get()` calls required to determine access, which maintains atomic operations and simplifies debugging.

QAPs Support: The structure supports the required QAPs through:

*   Segregation: Different data types (users, habits, habitLogs) are stored in separate collections, each with specific security requirements. This prevents mixing data with different access needs in the same collection.
*   Path-Based Ownership: Access control is primarily based on the path (e.g., `/users/{userId}/habits/{habitId}`), making it straightforward to write security rules that enforce ownership.

This structure supports secure list operations because security rules can easily restrict access based on the `userId` present in the path, ensuring that users can only list habits and habitLogs that they own.
